explanation: Not correct. The code calls memcpy(mhd_copy, buffer, size) where the destination mhd_copy was allocated with malloc(size), so the destination access is bounded. The only way the memcpy would read beyond the source object is if the caller violated the function’s precondition (i.e. passed a buffer that does not actually contain size bytes). MISRA Rule 21.17 forbids uses that result in out-of-bounds accesses, but it does not mean every API must defensively detect a caller’s misuse when the function’s contract requires the caller to supply a buffer of at least size bytes. In other words the library code itself does not demonstrably cause an out-of-bounds access — it assumes (as documented by the API semantics) that the caller provides a buffer of the given size. If you want to be conservative for MISRA, either (a) document the precondition explicitly or (b) add runtime checks where possible, but as written the agent A report describes a caller misuse rather than a definitive violation in the implementation.
